title: Laura Byrne defends returning to work after giving birth to daughter Marlie-Mae
text:
She returned to work six weeks after she welcomed her daughter Marlie-Mae Johnson in June.

And on Saturday, Laura Byrne defended going back to her day job at jewellery brand ToniMay, despite being bullied by other women.

'I realised being Laura Byrne and being a new mum could actually co-exist,' she told Stellar Magazine.

'It doesn't have to become my entire life': Laura Byrne (pictured) defended returning to work six weeks after giving birth on Saturday

The 33-year-old went on to say that other women - specifically other women with kids - were often behind the negativity.

'[They were] almost like, "How could you?" she said.

In the interview, Laura said while being a mother has added value to her life, it doesn't have to 'become her entire life'.

'I realised being Laura Byrne and being a new mum could actually co-exist,' she told the publication (pictured with fiancé Matty and baby Marlie-Mae)

Back in August, she told The Daily Telegraph's Confidential that she returned to work six weeks after her birth as it gives her a sense of identity.

'Work is so important for my mental health and when you have your own business, you have to be able to have that,' Laura explained.

'I am not putting any pressure on myself though, I will work as I am able to,' she added.

No pressure: The Sydney jewellery designer revealed that her little one hasn't been as challenging as she thought

Laura and Matty, 32, fell in love on the 2017 season of The Bachelor.

The couple became engaged in April this year.

The former reality TV stars are currently holidaying in Europe are in the middle of planning their 2020 wedding.
description: She returned to work six weeks after she welcomed her daughter Marlie-Mae Johnson in June.
authors: Ali Daher For Daily Mail Australia
